definition:
The [*Ulam spiral*]{} (or [*Ulam cloth*]{}) consists of integers,
starting from a given $n$ at the center, written in a spiral with the
prime numbers highlighted or emphasized in some way. For example,
writing a spiral with 42 at the center,

  ---- ---- ---- ---- ---- ---- ----
   90  67   68   69   70   71   72
   89  66   51   52   53   54   73
   88  65   50   43   44   55   74
   87  64   49   42   45   56   75
   86  63   48   47   46   57   76
   85  62   61   60   59   58   77
   84  83   82   81   80   79   78
  ---- ---- ---- ---- ---- ---- ----

and then simply blanking the composites, we obtain

  ---- ---- ---- ---- ---- ---- ----
       67                  71   
   89                 53        73
                 43             
                                
                 47             
            61        59        
       83                  79   
  ---- ---- ---- ---- ---- ---- ----

Carrying on this process in more layers will show that most of the
primes tend to fall on certain diagonals and not others.

This formation was first pondered by Stanisław Ulam with 1 at the
center. He tried carrying out the process much further, and also tried
different center values, but in each case the primes would cluster on
certain diagonals and sparsely populate others. Because almost all
primes are odd, it is easy to explain why they would tend to form
diagonals, but much more difficult to explain why they fall on certain
diagonals.

[1]{} Gardner, M. “Mathematical Recreations: The Remarkable Lore of the
Prime Number” [*Scientific American*]{} [**210**]{} 3: 120 - 128
